#Text=Nikobob Refuses a Crown
#Text=Almost
#Text=the first persons that Zella saw when she landed from the silver-lined boat at Regos were her father and mother .
#Text=Nikobob and his wife had been greatly worried when their little daughter failed to return from Coregos , so they had set out to discover what had become of her .

#Text=When they reached the City of Regos , that very morning , they were astonished to hear news of all the strange events that had taken place ; still , they found comfort when told that Zella had been seen in the boat of Prince Inga , which had gone to the north .

#Text=Then , while they wondered what this could mean , the silver-lined boat appeared again , with their daughter in it , and they ran down to the shore to give her a welcome and many joyful kisses .
#Text=Inga invited the good people to the palace of King Gos , where he conferred with them , as well as with Rinkitink and Bilbil .
#Text="

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Now that the King and Queen of Regos and Coregos have run away ,  he said , " there is no one to rule these islands .

column1: #Text=So it is my duty to appoint a new ruler , and as Nikobob , Zella 's father , is an honest and worthy man , I shall make him the King of the Twin Islands . "

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= Me ? " cried Nikobob , astounded by this speech .

column1: #Text=" I beg Your Highness , on my bended knees , not to do so cruel a thing as to make me King ! "
#Text=" Why not ? " inquired Rinkitink .
#Text=" I 'm a King , and I know how it feels .

#Text=I assure you , good Nikobob , that I quite enjoy my high rank , although a jeweled crown is rather heavy to wear in hot weather .

_	_	_	_

#Text= With you , noble sir , it is different , " said Nikobob , " for you are far from your kingdom and its trials and worries and may do as you please .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Very well , " replied Inga , " we will say no more about your being King .

#Text=I merely wanted to make you rich and prosperous , as I had promised Zella .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Please forget that promise , " pleaded the charcoal-burner , earnestly ; " I have been safe from molestation for many years , because I was poor and possessed nothing that anyone else could envy .

#Text=But if you make me rich and prosperous I shall at once become the prey of thieves and marauders and probably will lose my life in the attempt to protect my fortune .

#Text=Inga looked at the man in surprise .

#Text= What , then , can I do to please you ? " he inquired .

column1: #Text=" Nothing more than to allow me to go home to my poor cabin , " said Nikobob .
#Text=" Perhaps , " remarked King Rinkitink , " the charcoal-burner has more wisdom concealed in that hard head of his than we gave him credit for .

#Text=But let us use that wisdom , for the present , to counsel us what to do in this emergency .

_	_	_	_

#Text= What you call my wisdom , " said Nikobob , " is merely common sense .

_	_	_	_

#Text= If I had a hand , instead of a cloven hoof , I 'd like to shake hands with you , Nikobob , " said Bilbil the goat .

column1: #Text=" But the poor man must not have a cruel master , or he is undone . "
#Text=During the council they found , indeed , that the advice of the charcoal-burner was both shrewd and sensible , and they profited much by his words .
#Text=Inga gave Captain Buzzub the command of the warriors and made him promise to keep his men quiet and orderly -- if he could .

#Text=Then the boy allowed all of King Gos 's former slaves , except those who came from Pingaree , to choose what boats they required and to stock them with provisions and row away to their own countries .

#Text=When these had departed , with grateful thanks and many blessings showered upon the boy Prince who had set them free , Inga made preparations to send his own people home , where they were told to rebuild their houses and then erect a new royal palace .
#Text=They were then to await patiently the coming of King Kitticut or Prince Inga .
#Text=" My greatest worry , " said the boy to his friends , " is to know whom to appoint to take charge of this work of restoring Pingaree to its former condition .

#Text=My men are all pearl fishers , and although willing and honest , have no talent for directing others how to work .
